IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 8424 S1381-1169(12)00151-3 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.05.007 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Light-off curves of propane oxidation over the catalysts. Reaction conditions: 800ppm C3H8/2%O2/N2; 1000mlmin−1; GHSV, 60,000h−1. Fig. 2 Arrhenius plots for the combustion of C3H8 over Pt/CZ and Pt/SCZ catalysts. Fig. 3 The XRD patterns of Pt/CZ and Pt/SCZ catalysts as well as the supports. Fig. 4 IR spectra of CO adsorption on the fresh and oxidized Pt/CZ and Pt/SCZ samples. Fig. 5 IR spectra of propane adsorption on different catalysts and supports. Experiment condition: 250°C; 800ppm C3H8; N2 balance; flow rate, 100mlmin−1; adsorption time, 10min. Fig. 6 IR spectra of Pt/SCZ catalyst after (1) propane adsorption for 10min, (2) propane shut off and O2 introduced for 10min, (3) O2 shut off and propane introduced for 5min, and (4) propane introduced for 30min. Reaction conditions: 250°C; 800ppmC3H8; 2%O2 and N2 in balance; flow rate, 100mlmin−1. Fig. 7 IR spectra of propane adsorption on different catalysts after C3H8 +O2 co-adsorption at 250°C. Reaction conditions: 800ppm propane+2%O2; N2 balance; flow rate, 100mlmin−1. Fig. 8 Propane oxidation models on Pt/CZ (a) and Pt/SCZ (b). Participation of sulfates in propane oxidation on Pt/SO4 2−/CeO2–ZrO2 catalyst Bin Wang a Xiaodong Wu a Rui Ran a Zhichun Si b Duan Weng a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of New Ceramics & Fine Process, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China b Advanced Materials Institute, Graduate School at Shenzhen, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen 518055, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of New Ceramics & Fine Process, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China. Tel.: +86 10 62785986; fax: +86 10 62785986. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Sulfate addition enhances the oxidation activity of Pt/CeO2–ZrO2 catalyst. ► More active sites are created at the interface of Pt δ+/SO4 2−/CeO2–ZrO2. ► The interfacial sites are critical to the initial CH cracking and CC formation. ► The desorption of water and carbonates is feasible on the sulfated catalyst. The platinum catalysts supported on CeO2–ZrO2(CZ) and SO4 2−/CeO2–ZrO2 (SCZ) were studied for the reaction mechanism of propane total oxidation in an oxygen-rich atmosphere. The propane oxidation activity of Pt/CZ is greatly improved after sulfate addition. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, IR spectra of CO adsorption as well as IR spectra of C3H8 adsorption and oxidation. The specific surface area of the sulfated catalyst decreases from 40 to 14m2/g by the blocking effect of surface sulfates, and no obvious structure change is observed according to the XRD results. The spectra of CO adsorption indicate that Pt is on a more electronic-deficient state due to the electronic withdrawing effect of sulfates. Some more active sites are suggested to be generated at the interface of platinum and sulfates according to the activation energy calculation. The formation of such interfacial active sites plays an important role in CH cracking as evidenced by a series of in situ DRIFTS results of propane adsorption. A different reaction mechanism involving the accelerated cleavage of CH bond and removal of carbonates is presented for the catalyst. Keywords Propane oxidation Sulfates modification IR CH cracking Carbonate desorption 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbons has become the focus of many basic and applied catalysis researches because of its increasing importance for a lot of industrial processes: energy production (e.g., gas turbines) and in emission control (e.g., automotive exhausts) [1–5]. Platinum catalysts are employed more widely than transition metal oxide-based catalysts due to their superior stability and high oxidation activity at low temperatures [6–8]. With stricter environmental legislations are being implemented, it is highly recommended to explore catalysts with excellent low-temperature oxidation activity for the removal of hydrocarbons (HCs) during cold start transient, in which 50–80% of HCs is released into the air despite the application of catalysts [9]. In recent years, much work, such as the reduction/oxidation pretreatments [10,11] and the addition of acidic oxides (such as sulfates and tungstate) [12–17], has been done in order to improve the low-temperature hydrocarbon oxidation activity of catalysts. Sulfates are one kind of acidic additives widely used for improving the propane oxidation activity of platinum catalysts. However, it is still controversial for the role of sulfates in the reaction. Generally, it is considered that the state of noble metal has a determining effect on the hydrocarbon oxidation activity. Some research suggested that Pt showed a better activity at lower state (Pt0) [18,19]. The improvement of sulfates addition is attributed to the prevention of Pt oxidation by acid support during the oxidation process [20,21]. Contrarily, according to Burch's study [22], the activity improvement of sulfates addition comes from partially oxidized platinum active sites brought by the adjacent sulfates, which is important for CH bond activation. Corro et al. [23] proposed that the promoting effect on propane combustion is due to the interaction of surface sulfates with surface highly oxidized Pt atoms (Pt4+) at the edge of the Pt particles. Additionally, Andersson et al. [24] investigated the promotion of propane oxidation over Pt/Al2O3 by SO2 using transient experiments with TAP (temporal analysis of products) and reported that the formation of acidic sites at the Pt/SO4 2−/Al2O3 interface may generate a new reaction pathway consisting in the initial cracking of propane. Thus, there is no widely accepted explanation for the improvement with sulfate addition. Although the important role of new active sites at Pt–sulfate interface has been widely proposed, little direct proof was presented. Ceria–zirconia mixed oxides are widely used in three-way catalysts because of their superior oxygen storage capacity [25,26]. In order to clarify the effect of sulfates addition on the oxidation state and catalytic activity of platinum on ceria–zirconia support, a simple system, i.e., Pt impregnated on the sulfated CeO2–ZrO2 mixed oxides, was chosen in this work. In situ IR experiments for propane adsorption and oxidation were especially carried out to explore possible intermediate products and reaction mechanisms. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation CeO2–ZrO2 (CZ) mixed oxides were synthesized by a citric acid-aided sol–gel method. The nitrates Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and ZrO(NO3)2·5H2O were mixed according to the molar ratio of Ce:Zr=33:67. Citric acid was used as the complexing agent. Appropriate glycol was added as the dispersant followed by evaporation and peptization. The sol was heated at 100°C until a spongy yellow gel remained. The gel was then dried at 110°C overnight and submitted to decomposition at 300°C for 1h and calcination at 500°C for 3h to form the mixed oxides. The sulfated CZ (SCZ) was prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method using ammonium sulfate solution as the precursor. The nominal loading amount of (NH4)2SO4 was 10wt.% of CeO2–ZrO2 support. The impregnated support was dried at 110°C overnight and calcined at 500°C for 3h. For comparison, the pure CZ powders were also calcined at 500°C for 3h to try to keep similar preparation conditions. The Pt supported catalysts were prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method. Aqueous solutions of Pt (NO3)2 were used and the nominal loading amount of Pt was 1wt.%. The impregnated powders were submitted to drying at 110°C overnight and calcination at 500°C for 3h to obtain Pt/CZ and Pt/SCZ catalysts. The Pt/2%SCZ sample was prepared with the same method as Pt/SCZ, in which the sulfate amount is 2wt.% of CeO2–ZrO2 support. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) was conducted on a Japan Science D/max-RB diffractometer employing Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.15418nm). The X-ray tube was operated at 45kV and 150mA. The X-ray powder diffractograms were recorded at 0.02° intervals in the range 20°≤2θ ≤80° with 0.2s count accumulation per step. The specific surface areas of the samples were measured using the N2 adsorption isotherm at −196°C with the four-point Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method through an F-sorb 3400 instrument. The samples were degassed at 200°C for 2h prior to the test. The in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformed (DRIFT) spectra were recorded on a thermo Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector and a high temperature environmental cell fitted with KBr window. In each IR tests, about 40mg sample powders were used. For the CO adsorption experiment, the fresh sample was first pretreated in He (100mlmin−1) at 500°C for 1h and cooled down to room temperature (RT) for background collection. For each CO adsorption measurement, the sample wafer was first exposed to 1%CO/He stream (diluted from 5%CO/He by pure He) at RT with a flow rate of 100mlmin−1 for 20min and then flushed with pure He stream for 20min. IR spectra were recorded under pure He stream by accumulating 32 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1. For the experiment of the oxidized samples, the sample was firstly pretreated in 5%O2/He atmosphere at 500°C for 30min. In situ DRIFT spectra of adsorption species arising from propane chemisorption at 250°C were recorded in the range of 4000–650cm−1. Prior to propane chemisorption, the sample was placed in a crucible located in the high-temperature cell and heated up to 500°C in N2 flow (100mlmin−1). After the treatment at 500°C for 30min, the samples were cooled down to 250°C, and subsequently, flushed by 100mlmin−1 N2 for 30min to remove the physisorbed molecules for background collection. Then, the gas mixture containing 800ppmC3H8 in N2 (100mlmin−1) was passed through the sample at 250°C for 30min. The FTIR spectra were collected every 5min. The DRIFTS experiments of the reaction pathway were also performed. The sample powders were purged in situ in a N2 stream (100mlmin−1) at 500°C for 30min. The background spectra were taken in N2 atmosphere from 50 to 300°C at an interval of 50°C. After that, a gas mixture of 800ppmC3H8/2%O2/N2 was fed at a flow rate of 100mlmin−1. The spectra were determined by accumulating 32 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1 as a function of temperature at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. 2.3 Activity measurement The light-off catalytic activity for propane oxidation was tested in a fixed bed reactor made of stainless steel (i.d. 18mm). 0.2g of catalyst powders (diluted by coarse quartz particles to 1ml), sandwiched between two quartz wool layers, were inserted into the reactor. After a pretreatment at 500°C in N2 for 30min followed by cooling down to RT, the reactor was heated in the designed gas mixture from RT to 500°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1. The gas mixture was consisted of 800ppmC3H8, 2%O2 and N2 in balance with a total flow of 1lmin−1 and GHSV was 60,000h−1. The concentrations of the outlet gas were determined by a Thermo Nicolet IR 380 spectrometer. The propane oxidation steady state activity of both catalysts was tested at temperatures between 160 and 220°C. At each temperature, 800ppm C3H8 and 2%O2 (N2 balance) were introduced into the same microreactor as illustrated above and kept for 30min. 0.2g catalyst powders (diluted by quartz pellets to 1ml) were used and the GHSV was 60,000h−1. When the propane conversion reached stable, the concentrations of propane, CO2 and CO were recorded by a Thermo Nicolet IR 380 spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Propane oxidation activity The catalytic performance for C3H8 oxidation over Pt/CZ and Pt/SCZ is shown in Fig. 1 . For both catalysts, the products of the oxidation reaction are CO2 and H2O, no other products were detected. For the Pt/CZ catalyst, the propane oxidation starts at 280°C and the light-off temperature (T 50) is 360°C. After sulfation, the Pt/SCZ catalyst exhibits a much higher activity with the onset temperature is below 230°C and the T 50 is 250°C. It has been proven in our previous study that neither the CeO2–ZrO2 support nor the sulfated mixed oxides show little activity for propane combustion below 400°C under the same reaction conditions [2]. So the superior activity of Pt/SCZ catalyst should arise mainly from the interaction between platinum and sulfates. The propane oxidation activities of the catalysts were measured at different temperatures (160, 180, 200 and 220°C) under steady-state activity test. The apparent activation energies of the catalysts were calculated by assuming that under conditions of excess oxygen propane combustion over Pt is first order with respect to [C3H8] and zero order with respect to [O2] [27], and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . The calculated values are 57.2 and 83.1kJmol−1 for Pt/CZ and Pt/SCZ catalysts, respectively. The pre-exponential factor associated with the sulfated catalyst is larger than that of Pt/CZ sample, which is consistent with Burch's research on Pt/Al2O3 and the corresponding sulfated catalysts [22]. It is well known that the activity for short chain alkane oxidation over supported noble metals is highly dependent on the oxygen concentration. For platinum catalysts, the metal surface becomes self-poisoned by adsorption of oxygen at low temperatures under lean reaction conditions and consequently, the rate-limiting step should be the dissociative adsorption and cracking of alkane [27]. Thus, the larger pre-exponential factor may suggest a possibility of development of new active sites on the sulfated Pt/CeO2–ZrO2 catalysts which can facilitate CH bond activation. 3.2 Structure characterization The XRD patterns of the catalysts and supports are shown in Fig. 3 . All the samples present characteristic peaks of cubic ceria. No diffraction peaks of Pt or PtO are found on both catalysts. It can be seen that no obvious change of the diffraction pattern is found after sulfate addition. No diffraction peaks of crystalline sulfates were found on SCZ or Pt/SCZ, which may be related to the low calcination temperature (500°C) and the impregnation order of sulfates after the synthesis of ceria–zirconia mixed oxides. The BET surface area of the catalyst decreases from 40 to 14m2/g after sulfates addition, which may arise from blocking of the support pores by sulfates [24]. 3.3 IR spectra for CO adsorption The oxidation state of Pt is critical to the propane catalytic oxidation reaction, which is affected by the acidic additive and the reaction atmosphere. The oxidation of Pt during the combustion reaction is suggested to decrease the catalytic activity according to Yoshida's research [13,14]. Thus, CO adsorption experiments were conducted on the fresh and oxidized samples, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . The band at 2086–2090cm−1 is assigned to CO adsorption on Pt0 [28], and the broad band between 2110 and 2140cm−1 is related to partially oxidized Pt x+ species [29]. No obvious change is found in the IR spectra of the catalysts before and after the oxidation treatment. It indicates that CeO2–ZrO2 support with and without sulfate addition can stabilize the oxidation state of the noble metal, which is consistent with the results on the stabilization effect of ceria on platinum via a strong interaction between the noble metal and the oxide support [30]. Thus, it seems that the high propane oxidation activity of Pt/SCZ does not come from the improved oxidation resistance of platinum by sulfate modification, which is supported by the fact that the oxidation activities of both catalysts do not change after the oxidation treatment (not shown). It is also noted that compared with the Pt/CZ sample, the band of CO adsorption on Pt0 for Pt/SCZ shifts to a higher wavenumber and a broad band assigned to partially oxidized Pt x+ species appears, indicating that Pt on the sulfated support is in a more electronic-deficient state due to the existence of sulfate. This may account for the higher oxidation activity of Pt/SCZ [2,29]. The weaker Pt signals of Pt/SCZ may be related to the inhibition effect of sulfates on the adsorption of CO at platinum sites [31,32]. 3.4 IR spectra for C3H8 adsorption and oxidation Fig. 5 shows the spectra at 800–2100cm−1 and 2800–4000cm−1 for the adsorption of propane on different catalysts (Pt/CZ and Pt/SCZ) and supports (CZ and SCZ) at 250°C. On CZ support, the broad bands at ca. 1060, 1330, 1440 and 1610cm−1 are assigned to bicarbonate or carbonate, which is the same in our recent work [33]. Two negative bands at 3650 and 3760cm−1 are associated to vibrations of CeOH and ZrOH groups [34], which may be consumed or covered by the adsorbed propane species. After the sulfation of the support, the spectrum of propane adsorption on SCZ is quite different. An obvious negative band at 1390cm−1 which is assigned to SO bond appears and those bands assigned to carbonates or bicarbonate disappear [15]. The band at 1615cm−1, which is due to CC vibration, develops into a very strong adsorption [34]. At high wavenumber region, a band at 3670cm−1 appears which is assigned to some kind of SOH bond, and those negative bands associated with CeOH and ZrOH disappear. All these imply that the adsorption of propane is promoted on the sulfated support and the sulfates may act as important active sites. The impregnation of noble metal greatly improves the dissociative adsorption of propane. A distinct band at 1636cm−1 appears on Pt/CZ, which is assigned to δ(HOH) vibration of adsorbed water as one product of propane oxidation. This band shifts to 1627cm−1 on Pt/SCZ due to the overlapping with the band at 1615cm−1 assigned to the vibration of CC [34]. The bands assigned to bidentate carbonates (1135, 1230 and 1410cm−1) are observed on Pt/CZ, which almost disappear on the sulfated catalyst [33]. Again, a negative band at 1390cm−1 appears on Pt/SCZ, which decreases in intensity compared with SCZ support. This, accompanied with the disappearance of the band at 3670cm−1, suggests that new more active sites are generated instead of the sulfated cerium. In order to further investigate the possible surface reactions and active sites, the IR spectra of propane and O2 adsorption on Pt/SCZ catalyst are shown in Fig. 6 . After introducing propane for 10min, the main bands are 2055 and 1617cm−1 as well as the negative band at 1390cm−1. With the shut-off of propane and introduction of O2, the intensities of the bands at 1617 and 1390cm−1 become weaker, which indicates the consumption of the CC bond due to the reaction of adsorbed propane with O2. Meanwhile, the band at 2055cm−1 which is ascribed to CO adsorption on Pt disappears due to oxidation of CO [31]. When O2 is turned off and propane is introduced again, the spectrum turns to be similar to that of the initial case. With prolonging the time of propane adsorption, the intensity of the band at 1617cm−1 gets stronger and a new band at 3670cm−1 appears, which is similar to propane adsorption on SCZ shown in Fig. 6. It is noted that the SOH band does not rise up on Pt/SCZ until the time of propane adsorption is prolonged, which will be discussed later. Fig. 7 shows the in situ DRIFTS spectra for Pt/CZ, Pt/SCZ and Pt/2%SCZ catalysts in C3H8 +O2 flow. The obvious formation of carbonates with the bands at 1520, 1440, and 1370cm−1 occurs on Pt/CZ [33]. The band at 1330cm−1 is assigned to the vibrations of CH species [34]. It is noted that for the Pt/SCZ catalyst the carbonate bands are much weaker which may be related to the strong acidic nature of the sulfated support. Only a band at 1617cm−1 due to the CC vibrations and a negative band at 1390cm−1 related to sulfates are observed on Pt/SCZ. In order to try to explain different IR spectra of the two catalysts, the co-adsorption experiment of Pt/2%SCZ catalyst with a lower sulfate content was performed. It is found that not only carbonates but also adsorbed hydrocarbon intermediates (as indicated by the relatively strong band at 1330cm−1) are observed on the low-sulfates-containing catalyst. Thus, it implies that the propane oxidation reaction mechanisms of Pt/CZ and Pt/SCZ catalysts may be different, which co-exist on Pt/2%SCZ. 4 Discussion It has been shown by the in situ IR spectra (Figs. 5–7) that different reaction mechanisms may exist on the catalysts with and without sulfates modification. First, the oxidation state of platinum is affected by the adjacent sulfate species. According to the IR spectra of CO adsorption in Fig. 4, Pt on the sulfated support is on a more electronic-deficient state due to the electronic withdrawing effect of sulfates. Such Pt δ+/SO4 2−/CZ interfacial sites are suggested to be more active for the dissociated adsorption of propane than the platinum species on ceria–zirconia. It is evidenced in Fig. 5 that for the support material, the SO4 2−/CZ interface act as more preferable adsorption sites for propane with the appearance of the bands assigned to CC and SOH bonds instead of those associated with CeOH and ZrOH bonds. After the supporting of platinum, the CC and SOH bands disappear on Pt/SCZ due to the oxidation of adsorbed hydrocarbon with surface oxygen species on the catalyst at a temperature as high as 250°C. Based on these experimental results, it is plausible to present a different reaction model for Pt/SO4 2−/CZ catalyst in Fig. 8 . It is assumed that the first step of propane oxidation, i.e., the dissociative adsorption to propene at the Pt/SO4 2− sites, is accelerated greatly on Pt/SCZ catalyst [35,36]. The consumed oxygen in the sulfate may be compensated via the oxygen activation and spill-over effects of the adjacent platinum and ceria–zirconia mixed oxides. As shown in Fig. 6, the SOH groups appear again only after a prolonged time of propane oxidation without co-feeding of oxygen. Only after the active oxygens associated with platinum and ceria–zirconia mixed oxides have been consumed, the OH group appears as a product of participation of sulfates. Without the activation of platinum, the SOH band appears quickly on SCZ support as shown in Fig. 5. Thus, the modification of sulfate plays an important role in cracking of the CH bond, which is considered to be the control process in hydrocarbon oxidation. The sulfates not only act as active sites for the cleavage of CH bond but also play an important role in deep oxidation of propane. As shown in the IR spectra of propane adsorption and oxidation, strong bands of bidentate carbonates have been detected on Pt/CZ catalyst, which are considered as intermediate species [33]. Since carbonate species are easily to adsorb on base oxides such as CeO2, the coverage of CeO2–ZrO2 surface by carbonates would prohibit the deep oxidation of propane. Contrarily, no carbonates are observed on the sulfated catalysts due to the acidic nature of sulfates. This may also contribute to the improved propane oxidation activity of Pt/SCZ catalyst by accelerating the desorption of the reaction product. The above reaction mechanisms on different catalysts are supported by the DRIFT spectra, which seem to coexist on Pt/2%SCZ sample in Fig. 7. 5 Conclusion In an oxygen-rich atmosphere, the light-off temperature of Pt catalyst supported on ceria–zirconia mixed oxides for propane oxidation shifts to lower temperature by 110°C through the modification of sulfates. According to the steady-state activity measurements at different temperatures, Pt/SCZ catalyst has larger activation energy but a larger pre-exponential factor than Pt/CZ, which indicates that the addition of sulfate brings some more active sites. It is evidenced by the in situ IR spectra of propane adsorption and oxidation that the sulfates with the adjacent platinum play a determining role in CH bond cracking and the formation of CC species. The consumption of oxygen in the sulfates can be quickly compensated by the oxygen activation and spill-over effects of platinum and ceria–zirconia support. Additionally, the coverage of CeO2–ZrO2 surface by carbonates can be removed by the addition of the acidic additive. All these are beneficial for the low-temperature oxidation activity of Pt/SCZ catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The platinum catalysts supported on CeO2–ZrO2(CZ) and SO4 2−/CeO2–ZrO2 (SCZ) were studied for the reaction mechanism of propane total oxidation in an oxygen-rich atmosphere. The propane oxidation activity of Pt/CZ is greatly improved after sulfate addition. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, IR spectra of CO adsorption as well as IR spectra of C3H8 adsorption and oxidation. The specific surface area of the sulfated catalyst decreases from 40 to 14m2/g by the blocking effect of surface sulfates, and no obvious structure change is observed according to the XRD results. The spectra of CO adsorption indicate that Pt is on a more electronic-deficient state due to the electronic withdrawing effect of sulfates. Some more active sites are suggested to be generated at the interface of platinum and sulfates according to the activation energy calculation. The formation of such interfacial active sites plays an important role in CH cracking as evidenced by a series of in situ DRIFTS results of propane adsorption. A different reaction mechanism involving the accelerated cleavage of CH bond and removal of carbonates is presented for the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Participation of sulfates in propane oxidation on Pt/SO4 2−/CeO2–ZrO2 catalyst
